urn:contentItem:68J2-VJS1-JCS1-60JT-00000-00Revolve Group Inc at Needham Technology and Media Conference - Final2023-05-18T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:11:09ZLexisNexis051823a15586976.776Revolve Group Inc at Needham Technology and Media Conference - Final

Corporate Participants

* Mike Karanikolas

Revolve Group, Inc. - Co-CEO & Director

Conference Call Participants

* Anna Andreeva

Needham - Analyst

Presentation

ANNA ANDREEVA, ANALYST, NEEDHAM: Terrific. Good afternoon, everyone, and welcome to Needham's 18th Annual Technology and Media Conference. My name is Anna Andreeva. I'm a senior analyst covering consumer e-commerce here at the firm. And next up, we're very excited to have Revolve. From the company, we have Mike Karanikolas, who is the Co-Founder and co-CEO. Welcome, Mike.

MIKE KARANIKOLAS, CO-CEO & DIRECTOR, REVOLVE GROUP, INC.: Thank you. Happy to be here.

Questions and Answers

ANNA ANDREEVA: Great. So I figured we should start with -- Revolve is pretty unique, having been in the business for over 20 years now and having lived through various economic cycles. Can you talk about some of the learnings from the previous downturns that could help educate the company, how to navigate the current environment best, and how do you think Revolve has differentiated in this environment?

MIKE KARANIKOLAS: Yeah, definitely. I think the biggest learning living through past cycles, particularly the Great Recession of 2008, is that while those periods can be difficult, it's really an opportunity for businesses to separate themselves from the pack. And that was something that we saw in 2008, 2009, even though it was a very difficult period for us, it ended up being even more difficult for our competition.

And so when we got out on the other side, it was really fertile ground for us to grow on. It was like a forest fire had swept in and swept out a lot of the competition or weakened them significantly. And so I think that's the biggest learning just from a strategic direction perspective.

I think beyond that, certainly, there's a lot of stock market scenes around us, but when times are tough, you see really who has a good business that operates well and who doesn't. And so we've always prided ourselves on being great, not just from a growth perspective, but from a fundamentals perspective, from a profit perspective, and from a focus on the long term where we're never sacrificing the long term for something that's going on short term. I think that's really helpful entering a period like this.

And then I think the last thing we learned from that period, and it was many years ago when we were much younger and with not as much experience, but it's the importance of having a strong balance sheet. And that was one thing at the time that our balance sheet was not as strong.

We were self-funded. We had taken no investment up into that point and growing rapidly. And so cash was always tight, even when we were generating profits left and right. And so I think that's a big difference for us this time around where we've made sure we have a really strong balance sheet entering this period.

ANNA ANDREEVA: Perfect. You reported the first quarter a couple of weeks ago, and you talked about slowing trends as the quarter progressed and also weaker results in April as this younger consumer is pulling back. And this is what we hear across the industry, of course, as well.

The big silver lining from the print, in our view, was that the net ads of active customers continues to be really strong. And this was during the quarter when you pulled back in advertising. Can you talk about how do you see the composition of these new customers, full price versus clearance compared to last year, and just anything to call out in terms of LTV of these consumers versus your historic levels?

MIKE KARANIKOLAS: Yeah, definitely. As you say, that was a great aspect of the quarter that we're really happy with. Along with the inventory rebalancing and the cash generation, the new customer ads were a great aspect of the quarter. And for us, it's just kind of further validation that there's just a general weakening going on in terms of what we saw from some of the other customer cohorts, which I'd still say are still performing actually better than even the pre-COVID period, but just kind of comping towards last year when the consumer was still feeling quite strong.

So yeah, we were really happy to see that. And there's a couple drivers of it. One would be certainly we did have increased markdown product, which in general is not something we want, but there are periods we have to deal with that. And so that was helpful in driving new customer ads.

And then the other big thing that was helpful in driving new customer ads, which has been helpful for many quarters and is on a really nice growth trajectory, is our beauty segment, which is still quite small compared to the rest of the business, but historically has been a great driver of new customer ads. And that was a major source.

ANNA ANDREEVA: Okay. That's great. And yeah, the beauty trends have definitely been pretty encouraging. Anything that you see regarding the churn of the customer base lately, how do you guys think about retention and just the opportunities to continue to have her coming back to the site?

MIKE KARANIKOLAS: Yeah, definitely. So, first of all, it's with retention, we think in terms of higher strategic North stars of, try to create the best experience for the consumer in the space. And if you do that well, your retention is generally going to be good over time. There'll be certainly cycles where it's up or down, certainly the depths of COVID was one of those down examples, but you'll do really well over the long term. And historically, our retention numbers have been terrific.

So, in terms of retention of these recent cohorts, we'll have to see how it plays out. Historically, markdown retention is slightly worse than full-price retention, but it's still quite great, even in isolation. I think most -- many companies would kill to have those retention numbers that we even have on the markdown segment. So, we feel great about those ads. And again, we've been through many business cycles before, and we think every change is an opportunity, even if in the short term, there's a little bit of pain.

ANNA ANDREEVA: As the inventory correction continues, and you already made a lot of progress here in 1Q, and you're expecting more of a full-price business in the back half, how do you think about the net ads as we go through the year? Do you think there is a risk that more clearance consumer potentially drops off as the brand becomes less promotional, as again, the inventories are reined in, in the back half of the year?

MIKE KARANIKOLAS: Yeah, I mean, there certainly is a risk there. I mean, I might frame it as like, that definitely will happen. And it's overall a good thing. As much as we like to have more new customer ads, we like having healthier inventory, even more so. We still expect that number to be positive through the year, in terms of the active customers, but we do expect to see that number decel as we progress, as there's less markdown inventory available.

And of course, we'll have to see what happens economically. Obviously, it's a time, and I guess we've been seeing this for, many people have been seeing it for a number of quarters now, but it's only a time where there's risk the consumer gets weaker. And so if that happens, that will certainly affect our business.

ANNA ANDREEVA: There's been definitely some evidence of intensive promotional environment out there. I think across the board, if you look at the brands, if you look at the bigger players, department stores, et cetera. What are you seeing across the environment? And as inventories are getting gradually braved in, which I think some of the bigger players are definitely making progress there. Do you see any normalization in discounting quite yet?

MIKE KARANIKOLAS: Yeah, I mean, I think it depends on the segment, I think discounting has improved a bit in sort of the premium price points that Revolve operates at versus maybe a couple quarters ago, but it's still elevated compared to what we might normally see. And then if you look kind of in the more of the luxury price point, I think it's still quite elevated, and we're not really seeing any kind of alleviation there in terms of the level of discount that other luxury players are doing.

So I think that'll take longer to play out. And that's, I think, generally been true. Historically, it's actually a little bit more competitive, just because those brand names on the merchandise are so strong, and consumers sometimes follow the brand name versus the store that they buy from in terms of the level of price competition we see in the luxury space. So Forward will probably be impacted for a bit longer than Revolve.

ANNA ANDREEVA: And I think it's more of that aspirational consumer, right, that's been dropping off, probably both at Revolve and Forward?

MIKE KARANIKOLAS: Yeah, definitely. We've seen the higher-end consumer segments hold up a bit better than the more aspirational consumers, particularly on Forward. But that said, we are seeing, I'd say weakness across the board versus what we'd like to see, and certainly versus early last year, which was still kind of part of that post-COVID bull run. But certainly greater weakness in the aspirational consumer.

ANNA ANDREEVA: The one exciting aspect recently was seeing the first AI-generated billboard campaign that came out last month. How else are you thinking about potential for AI across the brands?

MIKE KARANIKOLAS: Yeah, we're incredibly bullish and excited about it. And granted, we're certainly technologists at heart. That's my background, actually, computer engineering. And we didn't talk about it much on this call, but we certainly have in the past just how much of a technology-led organization we are kind of through and through in terms of our DNA, how we go about things.

So, yeah, we're incredibly excited and bullish. And I don't get excited about every technology trend. This one, I'm quite excited about. The billboard campaign, I think, perfect example of it being put to great practical use where if you look at the speed that we're able to put that campaign together, if you look at the cost, if you look at the creative level and production level, we would not have been able to do that with traditional techniques on really any of those measures in the same way. And so it's really empowering there.

And as we look across the organization, it's really almost every aspect of the organization that has the potential touch. And in some areas, we are further along than others. And we've talked about how we've already been using it various places on the website, whether it's kind of fraud detection or various kind of personalization algorithms. But the step up in capabilities within the past 12 months on AI is just mind-boggling. And so for us, you know, continue to improve in those areas that I just mentioned.

Another big area that we're looking at with really great internal kind of initial results is on the fashion design side, assisting kind of in the design of products. I think in terms of search capabilities and different ways for the customer to browse the site, again, we've seen some really incredible things internally that aren't quite ready for prime time yet, but are really, really close. And really just every aspect of the business.

Again, it can touch, whether it's assisting customer service, whether it's kind of assisting operational areas. So we're excited about it. We're investing in it in a big way. And we think it can provide a competitive advantage to companies that are nimble and quick there.

ANNA ANDREEVA: Do you think inventory management could also benefit from that?

MIKE KARANIKOLAS: 100%. Yeah, kind of, as I said, it's really hard for me to think of an area of the business that it does not have the potential. And not just like one in a thousand chance, but like, reasonable potential to make a pretty big impact.

ANNA ANDREEVA: We noticed there was a limited-edition capsule launch as part of the AI campaign. Can you talk about that and some of the learnings from that?

MIKE KARANIKOLAS: Yeah, we were really excited with that capsule launch. And again, one of the learnings was certainly that it can be really powerful on the fashion design side. And on that case, we were just leveraging kind of the creative art, right. So it's more kind of leveraging it for the graphic arts with fashion design and graphic prints. But we felt like that capsule collection was really strong. We're really pleased with the results.

But then for us, we're using it internally to do some really cool design things that go beyond just graphic prints. And again, there's just a ton of potential. So we're excited for the coming month quarters. And I don't even think we're talking years here in terms of the impact that it can make.

ANNA ANDREEVA: Great, terrific. I know driving overlap between the two brands, Revolve and Forward is a pretty important initiative for the business. Can you talk about what you're seeing lately with that overlap and any new initiatives to drive that further? I think on the last call, you mentioned working on some navigation enhancements and inventory sharing between the two brands, which was new.

MIKE KARANIKOLAS: Yeah, definitely. Yeah. So those are two key things that we introduced. I think from a consumer standpoint, the navigation is going to be quite critical in the coming months and quarters. Just kind of bringing the websites a little bit closer together again, where it's much easier from the navigation for them to kind of cross back and forth between the two sites. And there's more sort of graphical emphasis placed on that capability.

So we ran tests on that. We found that it was really positive results and success. So we think that's going to provide lift going forward. From kind of an operational standpoint, really leveraging shared inventory capabilities, we think is going to be important for maximizing efficiency. So those were two key additions.

And then another thing that we have in the works, I think a good chance of it launching soon is within the Forward Renew program. We think there's an opportunity to bring that product to Revolve as well, which is, I think, not just an opportunity to expand the Renew program itself.

But again, just another one of those things that can bring Revolve and Forward closer together in the consumer's eyes, which will allow us to tap into that quite minimal current overlap between Revolve and Forward, right? It's kind of mid-single digits, sort of 5% range. And we think over the longer term, it has the potential to be 50%-plus in terms of the overlap. So it really has a long way to go.

ANNA ANDREEVA: I actually, I wanted to follow up on Forward Renew, as you're in a resale business now, which is definitely very interesting and timely. Can you talk about just any performance there? And just so making sure I heard this correctly. So you're thinking about a resale program for Revolve as well?

MIKE KARANIKOLAS: Yeah, it would essentially be bringing the same program over. With the Forward handbags in general, we think those are a really great sell to the Revolve customer. And then certainly if you're talking sort of the pre-owned handbags even more so. So we think it's a natural fit. We want to do it with similar branding. So again, it just kind of brings those two sites together. So it wouldn't necessarily be Revolve just completely separately also selling handbags. It would be part of the same program. So yeah, we think that's a big opportunity.

And then Renew, it's still quite small, but we think it has a lot of momentum. Obviously, the market there is huge. The handbag market is huge. The pre-owned handbag market is huge. We've seen a lot of good early metrics there.

And from a growth perspective, again, off of a small base, but I think the most recent quarter was 50%-plus quarter-over-quarter growth within that program. So we're hopeful we can drive that to much bigger places in the coming quarters.

ANNA ANDREEVA: And does it currently encompass only bags? And if yes, would you consider additional categories?

MIKE KARANIKOLAS: Yeah, we would consider additional categories. We think bags are the easiest, most natural fit. So that's certainly where we'll start. There's other things like watches or certain accessories that I think are natural there too.

I think it's less likely, at least certainly in the short term and even the midterm that we would get into apparel categories and things like that, with the exception of special vintage pieces. That's certainly the kind of thing that we could bring in something that's particularly special and unique. But in general, just the pre-owned apparel category, more broadly, we're not looking to get into it as big a way just because the economics are a little bit trickier there than I think with the handbags and some of the logoed accessories.

ANNA ANDREEVA: Understood. Okay, terrific. I wanted to ask about the own brands for the company. Just update us where you are with that. How are the brands performing? And you just announced a new one, a new collab with an international influencer, Cindy Kimberley. Just anything to pull out with that?

MIKE KARANIKOLAS: Yeah, we're super excited about the launch and in general, doing these influencer and celebrity collaborations is something that we want to do even more of. It really combines two skill sets that we're great at. Obviously, the brand marketing that we're known as kind of being a leader and innovator there and in connecting with these younger generations. And then also kind of the buying and design side in terms of the capabilities we're able to bring when partnering with the influencer to help create amazing designs that our customers are going to love. So we're super excited about that launch and we're looking to do more partnerships like that in the coming.

ANNA ANDREEVA: Okay, terrific. Revolve pulled back on the number of events during the quarter. Can you talk about how are you planning events as we go through '23 and just any update on the initiatives to reach and acquire customers today? Obviously, efficacy of marketing has become more choppy. You're one of the innovators for sure when it comes to using influencers and you mentioned brand marketing is something Revolve is very strong at. So we'd love to hear your thoughts.

MIKE KARANIKOLAS: Definitely. So I wouldn't characterize it as a pullback. The brand marketing cycle in particular has always come down to sort of timing of specific events and where we think there's opportunities. And you also have to stay fresh and exciting and interesting with brand marketing. There's some things that are mainstays like Revolve Festival, but we also try to mix things up every year.

So last year, we introduced some new events in the first quarter. Some of those were quite great, including a Super Bowl party in LA. This year, Super Bowl wasn't in LA and we decided it might not have the same impact in Phoenix doing that same party. So it's really just a timing issue. There'll actually be increased brand marketing activities in Q2 compared to Q1. So no pullback there. And we're always looking to invest in the long term through business cycles and certainly review those brand marketing investments as long-term investments.

ANNA ANDREEVA: Terrific. Can you talk about the category of performance? We love that you guys disclose fashion apparel and dresses and others. And those two have been more difficult just given the environment out there. And you also mentioned some of the going-out categories now are softer and this is on top of very strong business in those categories last year. So what are you doing to re-energize demand in those categories, specifically within apparel?

MIKE KARANIKOLAS: Definitely. For us, we're all about going where the consumer is going and where the consumer is. Obviously, we always want our sales to be as high as possible in any quarter and in every category as high as possible. But we're also disciplined. If we look at this year versus last year, post-COVID, there was just this huge boom in going out apparel and dresses and things of that nature. A lot of pent-up demand and things overshot a little bit. And so as a comparison, it's relatively weaker this year versus last year. That's fine. Wherever the consumer wants to go with the category she's interested in, that's where we'll go.

I think it can certainly be interesting from an analyst perspective because obviously different companies index differently in those categories. But for us, it's not anything we're trying to force. We're happy to provide the consumer whatever it is she's looking for.

ANNA ANDREEVA: And how big do you think the beauty category can get to the business? I know it's a relatively new initiative, typically high gross margin type of a category. And it has been doing well and is very additive in building baskets. Just curious, any thoughts on that?

MIKE KARANIKOLAS: Yeah. So over the long term, we would look to drive beauty to call it 10%-plus of the business. And we kind of look at what players in the space that have had a multi-decade head start on us have been able to do with categories like that. And that would be our goal there.

ANNA ANDREEVA: Anything specific to call out about just the performance there? Is this a new customer to Revolve coming in? Do you see it more as existing customers adding to baskets? Just curious about that.

MIKE KARANIKOLAS: Yeah, no, it's both. And it's one of the reasons we love the category so much. It's really great for bringing in new customers just because there's so many different products and brand names you can carry in there that can help introduce someone to Revolve. And then it's also great with existing customers in terms of increasing basket size and cross-shopping capability.

And yeah, a lot of things going on in beauty. We think we've done quite well with what we have, but we know we're missing a lot of key pieces. There's a number of key brands that we're missing, and we feel like we're making good progress behind the scenes, increasing that assortment, getting those brands in. And we're very hopeful that's going to happen over time.

From just a capability standpoint, we know we have work to do in terms of the various tools and ways to present those products to the customer on the website, right? Because our focus has been apparel, and so we're going to be making investments there.

And then obviously, I think from a brand perspective, continuing to invest in the right brand messages to make consumers think more of Revolve first over time when they're thinking about beauty versus -- Right now, we have some decent beauty share, but for a lot of our customers, we're certainly not their number one place to go for beauty, and we have the right investments and marketing messages that will change over time.

ANNA ANDREEVA: Okay. No, terrific. That makes sense. You guys are still expecting, I think, a modest increase in AOV for the year. Can you talk about how you think about that? Is that going to be driven more by units? We mentioned the beauty category, seeing momentum, so that's probably part of it. Or do you think it's more about improving average unit retail in the back half as the business becomes less promotional?

MIKE KARANIKOLAS: Yeah. So that projection is more centered around improving average unit retail, which we think should happen as the year progresses and as the inventory position.

ANNA ANDREEVA: Okay. Makes sense. Switching gears to margins, the one big positive takeaway from the print was recalibrating of the inventory position while improving the cash flow for the business as well. Can you talk about how you feel about inventories by brand, Revolve and Forward, and just any categories that the brands are still long in at the moment?

MIKE KARANIKOLAS: Yeah. So we feel like we've made a lot more progress on the Revolve side. The Revolve inventory is in a fairly good place, and certainly, I'd like to get it in a great place, but I think compared to where we were a couple of quarters ago, Revolve is in a really nice place right now. And again, the trends there are looking really good for the business.

For Forward, it's a bit behind Revolve, and I kind of mentioned that -- or alluded to that maybe from a competitive standpoint. And there's just different dynamics in the luxury realm. Again, there can be increased discounting when things turn a bit, and then also it can just take a little bit longer to cycle through the inventory because the turns are naturally slower than we've been with.

So that'll take a few more quarters. The Forward inventory isn't quite as healthy as the Revolve segment, but we've certainly been through this many times over operating the business for 20 years. So we're confident we can get that inventory to a good place. It might just take a few more quarters than Revolve.

ANNA ANDREEVA: Okay. But all in, should we still be expecting inventories to be more in line with sales? I think you said starting in the back half of the year?

MIKE KARANIKOLAS: Yeah, exactly. Yeah. I think we said on the call that end of Q2, we feel like we should be in a fairly good place.

ANNA ANDREEVA: Okay. Okay. Makes sense. Return rates have edged up for the business. And going back to the call, it sounded like there is a bigger strategic focus now for Revolve to affect that without compromising the consumer experience. And we thought that was a pretty big deal for Revolve potentially going forward. Could you talk about what that means? And do you think there are any investments that are necessary to see that? And what would be the rough timing for the company to affect? Because obviously, return rates are pretty important.

MIKE KARANIKOLAS: Yeah, 100%. So return rates have always been quite important for the business, but it hasn't been as big a focus the past three years, particularly 2020 and 2021. There were bigger things that we're focused on. And also return rates were depressed in that period. But certainly, with the recent increase, it has a meaningful impact on the financials of the business as we've seen.

So it's a huge area of focus. I'd say prior to the current period, again, there was a little bit of effort, but nothing major. It's not a major initiative within the organization.

When I say investments, I don't mean large capital expenditures. But there are things that have the potential to hit the margins, affect profitability in the short term. But I think long-term dividends will be paid over time.

When I say investments, I'm mostly talking organizational time and focus, as well as R&D efforts. Because the one thing with return rates is, aside from maybe putting some things in place on high-return customers that are maybe a little bit lower-handed and more tangible, it is a little bit more R&D in nature in that the ideas are more speculative.

But the things we have cooking, I think, look really good. I'm very hopeful that we're going to have some ideas that can hit in a really nice way, which the nice thing is if we have success there, it really impacts the business twofold, where not only do you get better operational margins, but you also get a revenue boost as your net becomes a lot higher percentage of the growth.

So big focus going forward. We're hopeful in the coming quarters we'll have some nice things to share there.

ANNA ANDREEVA: Okay. Some companies in the space have seen success using restocking fees. Of course, not something that the consumer loves, but at the same time, maybe unnecessary evil in this environment. Is that something that Revolve would consider? Not to put you on the spot.

MIKE KARANIKOLAS: Yeah, no. I'm just trying to think of the right way to sort of respond to it. We certainly already have a version of that in kind of extreme cases. But in general, I don't love stocking fees. And in general, where I want the organization's time and focus is on these win-win things. So I think there are some things we can do at the margins on some of those higher return rate customers.

But for me, it's about building long-term value a short-term number. And I want to help our customer. And so that's what I emphasized as we work on this. Figure out ways to help the customer, not to penalize them. I think we keep that North Star in mind. We're going to come up with really good things.

ANNA ANDREEVA: Okay. Terrific. Yeah, we look forward to hearing about that for sure, because that's a big deal. One interesting thing also you mentioned was cost savings from shipping and logistics initiatives, as you guys are doing some work when it comes to logistics. Can you provide some more color on that? And when do you think it might manifest as a positive impact to profitability?

MIKE KARANIKOLAS: Yeah, definitely. So on the earnings call, I think we mentioned some directional goals. And in terms of the number of basis points, we could shave on a run rate basis by the end of the year. I think also if you look at our implied guidance, it includes some reductions there.

So we have a number of things that we're working on. The full list is actually quite long. It's, call it, dozens of things that we're working on. But broadly, I'd maybe put things into three or so different categories.

So one would be things to kind of optimize our carrier utilization. So making sure we're using the right carrier, making sure we're negotiating with carriers in the right way, and in some cases, switching carriers. Particularly on the international side, we have opportunity to do that. And I think even on the domestic side, in some cases, that's one area we're working on.

Another area we're working on is just, call it, logistics optimization and location optimization. So the East Coast Pennsylvania warehouse is one of those things in that bucket. And that's much closer to operating at full capacity today than it was even, call it, two months ago. So we're hopeful that's going to provide some leverage on the bottom line.

There's other things I'd put in that bucket as well. We're actively pursuing a refulfillment center in Europe to help save on those costs. And as we scale, that's the kind of cost that should scale is our business scales there.

And then we're working on other things as well, like direct line hauls is something that we're looking into with a lot of promising early results. So it's a host of things. I mentioned returns as being a prime focus in the business. Optimizing these logistics in distribution costs is a prime focus as well.

ANNA ANDREEVA: Have you guys said what the time frame might be for a European fulfillment center?

MIKE KARANIKOLAS: Yeah, I don't think we've committed to a specific time frame, but I'd say that project is moving along, but at this point, we don't want to commit to a specific time.

ANNA ANDREEVA: Okay, understood. On international, you reported pretty strong results there and you talked about newer markets like India and also with China reopening. Could you talk about what are you seeing in more established markets? The macro picture I think continues to be still pretty difficult in Europe. Just curious what you're seeing there.

MIKE KARANIKOLAS: Yeah, definitely. In established Western markets and in developed markets, we're seeing a pretty similar picture to the US where consumer demand is softer and those markets aren't doing as well as we'd like. So Western Europe, Australia, places like that, we're definitely seeing soft demand trends.

But the international actually had great growth for the quarter as a whole and it's because internationally that's offset by a lot of these developing and emerging markets. Some of which just have great growth treacherous to begin with for us, but then also many of them haven't been as impacted by the current global economic situation. So areas like the Middle East, Latin America, we saw really strong strength.

Mexico in particular was quite exciting because it's grown to a fairly large base. It's actually become our fifth biggest country internationally and is growing -- I figure we said on the call, but I think close to triple digits. I can't recall if it's more than triple digits, but we'll call it close to triple digits.

So really great growth there, really great growth in India. India is still quite small, but still, I believe, we can call it 400%. So again, off of a small base, but quite exciting growth there.

ANNA ANDREEVA: What does the brand awareness look like in some of those countries for Revolve? I mean, very interesting, your comments on Mexico. So just curious.

MIKE KARANIKOLAS: Yeah, so actually Latin America in general, we have really strong brand awareness. And so now certain regions of Latin America, logistics are quite challenging. Long-term, that's still something we would like to unlock, but like Brazil, for example, from a brand perspective has a lot of potential for us, but we haven't really been able to unlock things from a logistics standpoint there. The tariffs are just outrageous shipping in products.

Mexico is kind of a sweet spot where it's a large market. It actually has our second largest call it social following among international regions in the world. Our logistics are decent there. We're working on making them even better. So it's really, I think those two pieces coming together in a nice way that are generating the growth.

ANNA ANDREEVA: Okay, understood. We got a question from an investor. So you've made a lot of progress with the inventories. And I think the low end of your gross margin implies some nice improvement. I think 100 basis points-plus in the back half and easier compares, of course, a part of that. But how do you think about the promotional intensity, whether it's for Revolve or for the industry?

MIKE KARANIKOLAS: Yeah, I mean, I think when the consumer is not in this healthier place, and also when there's broad discounting across the board, it does have impact on both our businesses. We like to say, and we've certainly seen it historically that Revolve is a bit less susceptible to what any particular competitor is doing at a given point of time. Revolve has a lot of whites around it.

But when there's match discounting, it definitely affects our consumers' mindset and there can be softness on the full price. So I think that'll continue to be a drag throughout the year. Despite that, we expect with the healthier inventory position margins to improve significantly certainly from the first quarter. And so again, we've been through a number of cycles and you just have to play the cycle as it comes and set yourself up for a great growth on the other side.

ANNA ANDREEVA: Right, definitely. The one unique thing about Revolve relative to the industry, so you've maintained profitability, you continue to generate strong cash flows. How do you think about potential for M&A? Valuations have certainly compressed and the buyback and how do you balance those two thoughts?

MIKE KARANIKOLAS: Yeah, I mean, it's tricky. We take being stewards of capital and people's investments very, very seriously. Another thing we like to say, and it is, I think, very relevant always is that Michael Mente and I are the two largest investors in Revolve and nearly half the company. So when I see that cash on the balance sheet, it's our investors cash, it's our cash and I want to do the best thing with it.

So I think as always, we're going to be thoughtful, we're going to be disciplined. It's really tough to say what the best use of that cash is going to be, but it's certainly something that we're actively thinking about as it continues to accumulate. Just how do we use it in a way to add the most value to our shareholders?

ANNA ANDREEVA: Okay, terrific. Makes sense. We have just a few minutes remaining. Just wanted to ask you, so what are you most excited about as we go through the year? Lots of initiatives, of course, longer term and near term still continues to be a little murky. Just curious on your thoughts.

MIKE KARANIKOLAS: Yeah, definitely. I mean, I think one of the things I'm most excited about is actually the opportunity to navigate this period. Certainly, it might be a bit more challenging economically, but what we've seen in the past, as I kind of mentioned in my earlier comments, is it's really time for companies like us to shine and can be a time for us to pull away from the pack, particularly as we get out on the other end of this.

And so, as is often said, when times get tough, a lot of companies that weren't focused on the right things, they struggle, or in order to survive, they have to cripple themselves in some way. And so, for us, I'm happy that I think it's a great period for us to get recognition for our business model, where we've delivered growth and profitability so consistently over the years. For a number of years, investors were focused mostly on growth. We've delivered both.

So, yeah, I'm excited. It's a great time for our business model to shine. I think on the other side of this, it can be a really fruitful opportunity for us.

And then beyond that, in terms of active things we're working on within the business, certainly the return rates, it's a challenge. But I'm incredibly excited about it as well, because it's something we haven't thought about in a big way in a number of years. And as we start thinking about it, realizing there's so much opportunity there.

And then the other thing I touched on earlier in the call, I know it's a buzzword right now, and I generally hate buzzwords, but I love AI. And not just from a conceptual standpoint, but more importantly, from a business standpoint, I think it's incredibly exciting. It's, I think, an exciting time to live right now in terms of seeing how things are going to change over the coming quarters and coming years. So, we're certainly excited about that as well.

ANNA ANDREEVA: Okay. Well, perfect. It's a perfect way to end on this note. Thank you so much, Mike, and thank you to everyone who listened in.

MIKE KARANIKOLAS: Thank you.

urn:contentItem:6GTK-K4C3-RS2G-J41T-00000-00Revolve Group Inc (RVLV )FY 2023 Conference Call Transcript2023-05-18T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T16:11:09ZLexisNexisRevolve Group Inc (RVLV )FY 2023 Conference Call TranscriptCall Participants:

Mike Karanikolas -- Co-Founder & Co-Chief Executive Officer (Revolve Group Inc)

Anna Andreeva -- Analyst (Needham & Company)


Presentation

Anna Andreeva:

Terrific, good afternoon, everyone, and welcome to Needham's 18th Annual Technology and Media Conference. My name is Anna Andreeva, I'm a senior analyst covering consumer e-commerce here at the firm. And next up, we're very excited to have Revolve. From the company, we have Mike Karanikolas, who is the Co-Founder and Co-CEO. Welcome, Mike.

Mike Karanikolas:

Thank you. Happy to be here.

Anna Andreeva:

Great. So I figured, we should start with Revolve is pretty unique, having been in the business for over 20 years now and having lived through various economic cycles. Can you talk about some of the learnings from the previous downturns that could help educate the company, how to navigate the current environment, best and how do you think Revolve is differentiated in this environment?

Mike Karanikolas:

Yeah, definitely. I think the biggest learning living through past cycles, particularly the great recession of 2008 is that, while those periods can be difficult, it's really an opportunity for businesses to separate themselves from the pack. And now, it's something that we saw in 2008, 2009, even though those were very difficult period for us. And then it would be even more difficult for our competition. And so when we got out on the other side, it was really fertile ground for us to grow on. It was like a forest fire had swept in and swept out a lot of the competition or weakened them significantly, and so I think that's the biggest learning just from a kind of strategic direction perspective.

I think beyond that, certainly and there's lot of kind of stock market seems around this, but when times are tough, you see really who has a good business that operates well and who doesn't. And so, we've always prided ourselves on being very not just from a growth perspective, but from a fundamentals perspective, from a profit perspective, and from a focus on the long-term, we're never sacrificing the long-term for something that's going on short-term and I think that's really helpful, entering a period like this.

And then you know I think the last thing we learned from that period and it was many years ago when we were much younger and with not as much experience. But it is the importance of having a strong balance sheet and that was one thing at the time that our balance sheet was not as strong, we were self-funded, we've taken no investment up until that point and growing rapidly and so cash is always tight, even when we're generating profits left and right and so I think that's a big difference for us this time around, where we've made sure we have a really strong balance sheet entering this period.

Anna Andreeva:

Perfect. You reported the first quarter a couple of weeks ago and you talked about slowing trends as the quarter progressed and also weaker results in April, as this younger consumer is pulling back. And this is what we hear across the industry, of course, as well. The big silver lining from the print in our view was that the net-adds of active customers continues to be really strong. And this was during the quarter when you pulled back in advertising. Can you talk about how do you see the composition of these new customers, full price versus clearance compared to last year, and just anything to call out in terms of LTV of these consumers versus your historic levels?

Mike Karanikolas:

Definitely, as you say, like that was a great aspect of the quarter. We're really happy with that and along with the inventory rebalancing and the cash generation that the new customer adds were a great aspect of the quarter and for us, it just kind of further validation that there's just a general weakening going on in terms of what we saw from some of the customer cohorts, which I'd still say, are still performing actually better than even the pre-COVID period, but just kind of copying towards last year when the consumer is still going quite strong. So, yeah, we're really happy to see that.

And then there's couple drivers of it. One would be, certainly, we did have increased markdown product, which in general is not something we want, but there are periods, we have to deal with that. And so, that was helpful in driving new customer adds and then the other big thing that was helpful in driving new customer adds, which has been helpful for many quarters and is on a really nice growth trajectory is our beauty segment, which is still quite small compared to the rest of the business, but historically, it's been a great driver of new customer adds and that was a major source.

Anna Andreeva:

Okay. That's great. And yeah, the beauty trends have definitely been pretty encouraging. Anything that you see regarding the churn of the customer base lately, how do you guys think about retention, and just the opportunities to continue to have her coming back to the site?

Mike Karanikolas:

Yeah, definitely. So first of all, with retention, we think in terms of sort of higher strategic north stars of try to create the best experience for the consumer in the space. And if you do that well, your retention is generally going be good over time, there'll be certainly cycles where it's up or down, certainly in the depths of COVID was one of those down examples, but we did really well, but long-term, and historically, our retention numbers have been terrific. So, in terms of retention of these recent cohorts, we'll have to see how it plays out, historically markdown retention is slightly worse than full-price retention, but it's still quite great even in isolation, right?

I think most many companies would kill to have those retention numbers that we even have on the markdown in that segment. So we feel great about those adds and again, we've been through many business cycles before and we think every change is an opportunity even if within the short-term, there's is a little bit of pain.

Anna Andreeva:

Okay. As the inventory correction continues and you already made a lot of progress here in 1Q. And you're expecting more of a full-price business in the back half, right? How do you think about the net adds, as we go through the year, do you think there is a risk that more clearance consumer potentially drops off as the brand becomes less promotional, as again the inventories are [Indecipherable] in the back half of the year.

Mike Karanikolas:

Yeah. I mean there is certainly is a risk there. I mean, like that definitely will happen and you know it's overall a good thing is, as much as we'd like to have more new customer adds, we like having healthier inventory, even more so. We still expect that number to be positive through the year in terms of the active customers, but we do expect to see that number, new sellers be progressive as there's less markdown inventory available.

And of course, we'll have to see what happens economically. Obviously, it's the time and I guess, we've been seeing this for -- many people have been seeing it for a number of quarters now, but we -- it's certainly a time where the consumer gets weaker and so if that happens that will serve to protect our business.

Anna Andreeva:

And there has been definitely some evidence of an intensive promotional environment out there. I think across-the-board, if you look at the brands, if you look at the bigger players, department stores, etc, what are you seeing across the environment and as inventories are getting gradually rated which I think some of the bigger players are definitely making progress there, do you see any normalization in discounting quite yet.

Mike Karanikolas:

Yeah. I mean I think it depends on the segment. I think discounting has improved a bit in sort of the premium price points that Revolve operates at versus maybe a couple of quarters ago, but it's still elevated compared to what we might normally see. And then if you look kind of in the more the luxury price point, I think it's still quite elevated and we're not really seeing any kind of alleviation there in terms of the level of discount and other luxury players are doing.

So, I think that will take longer to play out and that's I think generally been true historically, it's actually a little bit more competitive just because those brand names on the merchandise are so strong and consumers on the smaller brand name versus the store that they buy from, in terms of the level of price competition we've seen the luxury space. So, Forward will be probably be impacted for a bit longer than Revolve.

Anna Andreeva:

And I think it's more of that aspirational consumer right that's been dropping off probably both at Revolve and Forward.

Mike Karanikolas:

Yeah, definitely we've seen the higher-end consumer segments hold up a bit better than the more aspirational consumer briefly on Forward. But that said, we are seeing I'd say weakness across-the-board versus what we'd like to see and certainly versus early last year, which was still kind of part of that was COVID bull run, so but certainly greater weakness of the aspirational.

Anna Andreeva:

The one exciting aspect recently was seeing the first AI-generated billboard campaign that came out last month, how else are you thinking about potential for AI across the brands?

Mike Karanikolas:

Yeah we're incredibly bullish and excited about it and you know, granted we're certainly technologists in heart, that's my background actually, computer engineering and we didn't talk about much on this call, but we certainly have in the past is how much of a technology-led organization we are kind of through and through, it runs in our DNA and how we go about things. So yeah we're incredibly excited and bullish and I don't get excited about every technology trends.

This one I'm quite excited about. The billboard campaign I think, perfect example of it being put to great practical use, where if you look at the speed we're able to put that campaign together. If you look at the cost, if you look at the accretive level and production level, we would not have been able to do that with traditional techniques on really any of those measures in the same way. And so it's really empowering there and as we look across the organization, it's really almost every aspect of the organization that has the potential to touch. In some areas, we are further along than others, and we've talked about how we've already been using it.

I'm various pleased on the website, whether it's kind of fraud detection or various kind of personalization algorithms, but the step-up in capabilities within the past 12 months on AI is just mind-boggling. And so for us continue to improve in those areas that I just mentioned, another big area that we're looking at with really great internal kind of initial results is on the fashion design side a sustained kind of in the design of products.

I would like -- I think in terms of search capabilities and different ways for the customer to browse the site again, we've seen some really incredible things internally that are quite ready for prime-time yet, but I really believe close and really just every aspect of the business. Again, it can touch whether it's assisting customer service, whether it's a kind of assisting the operational areas. So, we're excited about it, we're investing in it in a big way and we think it can be a -- provide a competitive advantage to the companies that are nimble and quick there.

Anna Andreeva:

Do you think the inventory management could also benefit from that?

Mike Karanikolas:

100%. Yeah, kind of, as I said, it's really hard for me to think of an area of the business that it does not have the potential and not just like one in a 1,000 chance, but like the reasonable potential to make it pretty big.

Anna Andreeva:

We noticed there was a limited edition capsule launch as part of the AI campaign, can you talk about that and some of the learnings from that?

Mike Karanikolas:

Yeah, we're really excited with that capsule launching, and again one of the learnings was certainly that it can be really powerful on the fashion design side. And in that case, we were just leveraging kind of creative art, right? So, it is more kind of leveraging it for the graphic arts with fashion design that includes graphic prints, but we felt like that capsule section was really strong. We're really pleased with the results.

But then for us, we're using it internally to do some really cool design things that go beyond just graphic prints and again, there's just a ton of potential. So, we're excited for the coming month, quarters and I'd only think we're talking years here in terms of the impact that it can make.

Anna Andreeva:

Okay, terrific. I know driving overlap between the two brands Revolve and Forward is a pretty important initiative for the business. Can you talk about what you're seeing lately with that overlap any new initiatives to drive that further? I think on the last call you mentioned working on some navigation enhancements and inventory sharing between the two brands which was new.

Mike Karanikolas:

Yeah, definitely. Yes, yes. So those are two key things that we introduced. I think from a consumer standpoint, the navigation is going to be quite critical in the coming months and quarters, just kind of bringing the websites a little bit closer together, again where it's much easier from the navigation for them kind of to cross back-and-forth between the two sites and there's more sort of graphical emphasis placed on that capability. So, we ran a test on that, we found that it was really positive results and success and we think that's going to [Indecipherable] going forward. From kind of an operational standpoint, really leveraging shared inventory capabilities, I think it's going to be important for maximizing efficiency.

So, those were two key additions and then another thing that we have, you know, in the works I think good chance of launching soon just within the Forward renew program, we think there is opportunity to bring that product to Revolve as well, which is I think not just an opportunity to expand the renew program itself, but again, just another one of those things that can bring Revolve and Forward closer to get in the consumers' eyes, which will allow us to tap into that. Quite minimal current overlap between Revolve and Forward, it's kind of mid-single digits at sort of 5% range. And we think over the long-term that it has the potential to be 50% plus in terms of the overlap. So it really has a long way to go.

Anna Andreeva:

I actually, I wanted to follow up on Forward Renew as you're in a resale business now, which is definitely very interesting and timely. Can you talk about just any performance there and just making sure I heard this correctly, so you're thinking about a resale program for Revolve as well?

Mike Karanikolas:

Yeah, I would essentially be bringing the same program over with the Forward handbags in general, we think those are really great sell to the Revolve customer, and then certainly, if you're talking sort of the pre-owned handbags even more so. So, we think it's a natural fit. We want to do with similar branding. So again it just kind of brings those two sites together. So, it wouldn't necessarily be Revolve just completely separately also selling handbags, which is part of the same corporate program.

Yeah, we think that's a big opportunity and then renew it's still quite small, but we think it has a lot of momentum. Obviously the market there, it's huge the handbag market is huge. The pre-owned handbag market is huge. We've seen a lot of good early metrics there. And from a growth perspective, again off of a small base, but I think the most recent quarter was 50% plus quarter-over-quarter growth within that program. So, we're hopeful we can drive that much bigger places in the coming quarters.

Anna Andreeva:

And does it currently encompass only bags and would you consider, if yes, would you consider additional categories?

Mike Karanikolas:

Yeah, we would consider additional categories, we think bags are the easiest and most natural fit. So that's certainly where we'll start. There's other things like watches or certain accessories that I think are natural there too. I think it's less likely, it would be certainly in the short-term and even the mid-term that we would get into apparel categories and things like that. With the exception of special vintage pieces, right, that's certainly is kind of thing that we could bring in, something that's particularly special and unique. But in general sort of just the pre-owned apparel category more broadly, we're not looking to get into as big a way just because the economics are a little bit trickier there than I think with the handbags and some of that little bit of accessories.

Anna Andreeva:

Understood. Okay, terrific. I wanted to ask about the owned brands for the company, just update us where you are with that, how are the brand's performing and you just announced a new one -- a new collab with international influencer, Cindy Kimberly, just anything to call out with that.

Mike Karanikolas:

Yeah, we're super-excited about the launch and in general, doing these influencers and celebrity collaborations are something that we wanted to do even more of it, it really combines two skill-sets that we are great at and obviously the brand marketing that we're known as kind of an innovator there and in connecting with these younger generations and then also kind of the buying and design side in terms of the capabilities, we're able to bring when partnering with the influencer to help create amazing designs, that our customers are going to love. So we're super-excited about that launch and we're looking to do more partnerships like that in the coming months.

Anna Andreeva:

Okay, terrific. Revolve pulled back on the number of events during the quarter, can you talk about how you're planning events as we go through '23 and just any update on the initiatives to reach and acquire customers today, obviously efficacy of marketing has become more choppy, you're one of the innovators for sure when it comes to using influencers, and you mentioned brand marketing is something Revolve is very strong at, so would love to hear your thoughts.

Mike Karanikolas:

So. I wouldn't characterize it is as a pullback. The brand marketing cycle in particular has always come down to sort of timing of specific events and where we think there's opportunities and you also have to stay fresh and exciting and interesting with brand marketing. There are some things that are mainstays like Revolve Festival, we also try to mix things up every year. So last year we introduced some new events in first quarter, some of those were quite great including a super bowl party in LA. This year's super bowl wasn't in LA and we decided it might not have the same impact in Phoenix do that same party. So it's really just a timing issue, there are actually increased brand marketing activities in Q2 compared to Q1. So no pullback there and we're always looking to invest in the long-term through business cycles and certainly we view those brand marketing investments as long-term investments.

Anna Andreeva:

Okay, terrific. Can you talk about the category performance, we love that you guys disclosed fashion apparel and dresses and others. And those have been more difficult, just given the environment out there. And you also mentioned some of that going out categories now are softer and this is on top of very strong business in those categories last year, so what are you doing to re-energize demand in those categories, specifically within apparel?

Mike Karanikolas:

Definitely, for us, we're all about going where the consumer is going and where the consumer is. So, obviously we always want our sales to be as high as possible in any quarter and in every category, as high as possible, but we're also disciplined, right? So if you look at this year versus last year, post-COVID there is just a huge movement going out in apparel and in dresses and things of that nature. A lot of pent-up demand, right, and things overshot a little bit and so as a comparison, it's relatively weaker this year versus last year, that's fine.

Wherever the consumer wants to go, the category she is interested and that is where we will go. So, it's I think can [Indecipherable] from like an analyst perspective, because obviously different companies index differently in those categories, but for us it's not anything we're trying to force, we're happy to provide the consumer whatever that she is looking for.

Anna Andreeva:

And how big do you think the beauty category can get to the business? I know it's a relatively new initiative, typically high gross margin type of a category and it has been doing well and it's very additive, right, in building baskets, just curious any thoughts on that?

Mike Karanikolas:

Yeah, so over the long-term, we would look to drive beauty to call it 10% plus of the business and we are kind of looking at what, players in this space that have had a multi-decade head start on us, have been able to do with categories like that and that will be our goal there.

Anna Andreeva:

Anything specific to call out about just the performance there. Is this a new customer to Revolve coming in, do you see it more as existing customers adding to baskets, just curious about that.

Mike Karanikolas:

Yeah, no, it's both. And that is one of the reason, we love the category so much, it's really great for bringing in new customers because there are so many different products and brand names you can carry that can help introduce someone to Revolve and then it's also great with existing customers in terms of increasing basket size and cross-shopping capability and yeah, a lot of things going on in beauty. We think we've done quite well with what we have and we know we're missing a lot of key pieces, there is a number of key brands that we're missing.

And we feel like we're making good progress behind the scenes, increase in that assortment, getting those brands in and we're very hopeful that's going to happen over time. From just a capability standpoint, we know we have work to do in terms of the various tools and the way we present those products to the customer on the website, our focus has been apparel. And so we're going to be making investments there, so and then, obviously I think from a brand perspective continuing to invest in the right brand messages to make consumers think more of Revolve.

First, over time, when they're thinking about beauty versus right now we have some decent beauty share, but offer a lot of our customers, we're certainly not their number-one place to go for beauty and we have to create investments and marketing messages that will change over time.

Anna Andreeva:

Okay, okay, no terrific. That makes sense. You guys are still expecting, I think a modest increase in AOV for the year. Can you talk about how you think about that, is that going to be driven more by units, we mentioned the beauty category seeing momentum. So that's probably part of it or do you think it's more about improving average unit retail in the back half as the business becomes less promotional?

Mike Karanikolas:

So that projection is more centered around improving average unit retail, which we think should happen as the year progresses and as the inventory position.

Anna Andreeva:

Okay, okay, makes sense. Switching gears to margins. The one big positive takeaway from the brand was re-calibrating of the inventory position, while improving the cash flow for the business as well. Can you talk about how you feel about inventories by brand, Revolve and Forward and just any categories that the brands are still longing at the moment?

Mike Karanikolas:

Yeah, so we could have been made, a lot more progress on the Revolve side, the Revolve inventory is in a fairly good place and certainly, I'd like to hit in the great place, but I think compared to where we were a couple of quarters ago Revolve is in a really nice place right now. So and again sort of trends there are looking really good for the business. For Forward, it's a bit behind Revolve and I kind of mentioned that -- alluded that maybe from a competitive standpoint.

And then just different dynamics in the luxury realm. Again, there can be increased discounting when things turn a bit and then also, it can just take a little bit longer for the cycle to the inventory, because the turns are naturally slower than it looks. So that will take a few more quarters. The Forward inventory isn't quite as healthy as the Revolve segment, but we certainly been through this many times over operating the business for up to 20 years. So, we're confident we can get that inventory to a good place, it might just take a few more quarters and evolve[Phonetic].

Anna Andreeva:

Okay, but all in, should we still be expecting inventories to be more in line with the sales, I think you said starting in the back half of the year.

Mike Karanikolas:

Yeah, exactly, yeah. I think we said on the call that's kind of end of Q2, we felt like we should be in a fairly modest one.

Anna Andreeva:

Okay, it makes sense. Return rates have edged up for the business. And going back to the call it sounded like there is a bigger strategic focus now for Revolve to effect that without compromising the consumer experience and we thought that was a pretty big deal for Revolve potentially going forward. Could you talk about what that means and do you think there are any investments that are necessary to see that and what would be the rough timing for the company to effect, because obviously return rates are pretty important?

Mike Karanikolas:

Yeah, 100%. Yes, so return rates have always been quite important for the business, but it hasn't been as big a focus the past, call it, three years, particularly 2020 and 2021, there were bigger things that we're focused on and also return rates were depressed in that period, but certainly, with the recent increase it has a meaningful impact on the financials of the business as we see. So, it's a huge area of focus. I'd say prior to the current period. Again, there was -- if there is a little bit of effort, but nothing major -- no major initiative within the organization.

When I say investments, I don't mean large capital expenditures, but there are things that have the potential at the margins, affect profitability in near term, but I think long-term dividends will be paid over time. When I say investments are mostly talking organizational time and focus as well as kind of R&D efforts, because the one thing with return rates is aside from maybe putting some things in place on high-returning customers that maybe a little bit kind of lower-hanging fruit in more tangible. It is a little bit more R&D in nature in that the ideas are more speculative, but the things we have cooking, I think look really good, as I'm very hopeful that we're going to have some ideas that can hit in a really nice way which the nice thing is, if we have success there it really impacts business twofold and not only do you get better operational margins, but you also get a revenue boost as your net becomes a higher percentage of the growth. So big focused and important, we're hopeful in the coming quarters we'll have some nice things to share there.

Anna Andreeva:

Okay. Some companies in this space have seen success using restocking fees. Of course, not something that the consumer loves, but at the same time may be unnecessary evil in this environment, is that something that Revolve would consider? Not to put you on the spot..

Mike Karanikolas:

Yeah, no, I'm just trying to think of the right way to sort of respond to it. We certainly already have a version of that in kind of extreme cases. But in general, I don't love talking to [Speech Overlap] in general, where I want the organization's time and focus is on these win-win things, so I think there are some things, we can do the margins on some of those higher-return rate customers, but for me it's about building long-term value versus short-term number and I want to help our customer. And so that's what I emphasized, we work on this is really to help the customer, not to penalize them. I think we keep that Northstar in mind, we're going to come up with really good one.

Anna Andreeva:

Okay. Okay, terrific. We look forward to hearing about that for sure, because that's a big deal. One interesting thing also you mentioned was cost-savings from shipping and logistics initiatives as you guys are doing some work when it comes to logistics, can you provide some more color on that and when do you think that might manifest as a positive impact to profitability?

Mike Karanikolas:

Definitely. So, on the earnings call, I think we mentioned some directional goals in terms of the number of basis points we could scrub shave on a run-rate basis by the end of the year. I think also if you look at our implied guidance, and it's going to include some reductions there. So we have a number of things that we're working on, the full list is actually quite long, it's -- call it, dozens of things that we're working on. But broadly, I'd maybe put things into three or so different categories, the one would be thing to kind of optimize our carrier utilization for making sure we just had the right carrier, making sure we're negotiating with carriers in the right way, and in some cases switching carriers, particularly on the international side, we have opportunity then, I think even on the domestic side, in some cases, that's one area we're working on.

Another area we're working on is just, call it, sort of logistics optimization and location optimization. So, the East Coast Pennsylvania warehouse is one of the things in that bucket and that's much closer to operating at full capacity today than it was even call it two months ago. So, we're hopeful that's going to provide some leverage on the bottom line. There's other things I'd put in that bucket as well. We're actively pursuing a re-fulfillment center in Europe to help save on those costs. And as we scale, that's the kind of costs that should scale as our business scales there. And then we're working on other things as well like a direct line hauls is something that we're looking into, a lot of promising early results. So it's a host of things I mentioned returns has been a prime focus in the business, optimizing these logistics and distribution costs is a prime focus as well.

Anna Andreeva:

Have you guys said what the timeframe might be for the European fulfillment center?

Mike Karanikolas:

Yeah. I don't think we've committed to a specific timeframe, but I'd say that project is moving along. But at this point, I don't want to commit to a specific time.

Anna Andreeva:

Okay, okay, understood. On international, you reported pretty strong results there and you talked about, newer markets like India and also with China reopening. Could you talk about what are you seeing in more established markets, the macro picture, I think continues to be still pretty difficult in Europe just curious what you're seeing there.

Mike Karanikolas:

Yeah, definitely, in kind of established Western markets and developed markets, we're seeing a similar -- a pretty similar picture to the US where the consumer demand is softer and those markets aren't doing as well as we'd like so, Western Europe, Australia and places like that, we're definitely seeing soft demand trends, but the international actually had great growth for the quarter as a whole. And it's because actually that's offset by a lot of these developing and emerging markets, some of which you just have great growth to begin with for us, but then also many of them are -- haven't been as impacted by the current global economic situation.

So, areas like the Middle-East, Latin-America we saw really strong strength, Mexico in particular was quite exciting, because it has grown to a fairly large base. It's actually become our fifth biggest country internationally and is growing, I think what we said on the call, but I think call it close to triple-digits, I can't recall if its more than triple-digits or close to -- or call it close to triple-digits. So, great growth there, really great growth. India is still quite small, but still I believe growing at, call it, 400%, so again off of a small base, but quite exciting growth there.

Anna Andreeva:

What is the brand awareness look like in some of those countries for Revolve and very interesting your comments on mix, just curious?

Mike Karanikolas:

Yeah, so actually Latin-America in general we have really strong brand awareness. And so certain regions of Latin-America logistics are quite challenging. In long term, that's still like to unlock like Brazil, for example from our brand perspective has lot of potential for us, but we haven't really been able to unlock things from a logistics standpoint, there the tariffs are just outrageous shipping in products.

Mexico is kind of a sweet-spot where it's a large market, it actually has our second-largest, call it, social following among international regions in the world. Our logistics are decent there, we're working on making them even better. So it's really, I think, those two pieces coming together in a nice way that are generating the growth.

Anna Andreeva:

Okay, understood. We've got a question from an investor. So you've made a lot of progress with the inventories and I think the low end of your gross margin implies some nice improvement, I think 100 basis points plus in the back-half and easier compares of course, a part of that, but how do you think about the promotional intensity, whether it's for Revolve or for the industry.

Mike Karanikolas:

Yeah. I mean, I think when the consumer is not in his healthier place and also when there's broad discounting across-the-board, it does have impact on both our businesses, we -- I'd like to see -- and we'd like to say and we've certainly seen historically that Revolve is a bit less susceptible to what any particular competitor is doing at any given point in time at all, Revolve has a lot of [Technical Issues] around it, but when there's mass discounting, it definitely affects our consumers' mindset and there can be softness on the full-price, so I think that will continue to be a drag throughout the year, despite that we expect we will be healthier inventory position margins to improve significantly. Certainly from the first quarter and so again, we've been through a number of cycles and you just have to play the cycle as it comes in and set yourself up for a great growth on the other side.

Anna Andreeva:

Right, definitely. The one unique thing about Revolve relative to the industry. So, you've maintained profitability, you continued to generate strong cash flows. How do you think about potential for M&A valuations have certainly compressed and the buyback, and how do you balance those two thoughts?

Mike Karanikolas:

Yeah. I mean it's tricky, we take being stewards of capital and people's investments very very seriously, another thing we'd like to say I think very relevant always is that Michael Mente and I are the two largest investors in Revolve and nearly half the company, so when I see that cash on the balance sheet, it's our investor's cash, it's our cash and I wanted to do the best thing with it. So, I think, as always, we're going be thoughtful, we're going to be disciplined. It's really tough to say what the best use of that cash is going to be, but it's certainly something that we're actively thinking about as it continues to accumulate, just how do we use it and maybe to add the most value to our shareholders.

Anna Andreeva:

Okay, so if that makes sense. We have just a few minutes remaining. Just wanted to ask you, so what are you most excited about as we go through the year, lots of initiatives, of course, longer-term, near term still continue to be a little murky, just curious on your thoughts.

Mike Karanikolas:

Yeah, definitely. I mean I think one of the things I'm most excited about is actually the opportunity to navigate this period. You know, certainly, it might be a bit more challenging economically, but what we've seen in the past is, as I kind of mentioned in my earlier comments is, it's really time for companies like us to shine and time for us to pull away from the pack, particularly as we get on the other end of the business. So, as it is often said, when times get tough, a lot of companies that weren't focused on the right things, they struggle or in order to survive, they have to cripple themselves in some way.

And so, for us, I'm happy that I think it's a great period for us to get recognition for our business model, where we've delivered growth and profitability so consistently over the years for a number of years investors focus mostly on growth, we delivered both, so yes so I'm excited. It's a great for this business model to shine. I think on the other side of this, it can be a really fruitful opportunity for us. And then beyond that in terms of active things, we're working on within the business, certainly, the return rates is a challenge, but I'm incredibly excited about it as well because it's something we haven't thought about in a big way in a number of years and as we start thinking about it, realizing there's so much opportunity there.

And then the other thing I touched on earlier in the call, I know it's a buzzword right now and I generally hate buzzwords but I love it, and yeah, no, not just from a conceptual standpoint, but more importantly from a business standpoint. I think it's incredibly exciting -- it's I think an exciting time to live right now in terms of seeing how things are going to change over the coming quarters and coming years. So we're certainly excited about that as well.

Anna Andreeva:

Okay, well, perfect. It's a perfect way to end on this note. Thank you so much, Mike, and thank you to everyone for listening.
